page.title: 01REVIEW OF WEDMORE AREA
page.content: The D-block is situated on an island of land rising 100ft from the peat levels bounded to the north by Mendip, limestone hills rising to 1000ft. Settled since prehistory, a royal area for hunting in Alfred the Great's time and Wedmore the centre for the peace treaty with the Danes, first drained by Glastonbury monks, the rich dairy land is dotted with villages and farms. Local stone builds solid houses and square-towered churches enriched by the wool trade, witnessed on the inn sign of the Sexey's Arms. Sir Hugh Sexey, an Elizabethan millionaire, owned an estate continuing in the school's name today. Commuters using the nearby M5 have swelled the rural community still following country traditions and customs.
